Diagnosis.
Protoneura macintyrei
shares male cercus longer than wide and with a laminar lobe on medial surface with
P. calverti
,
P. klugi
,
P. scintilla
,
P. tenuis
, and
P. woytkowskii
( Figs. 101b, c ; 107–108b, c; 114b, c; 116b, c; 118b, c). Among them, it shares male cerci and paraprocts no longer than S10 length with
P. klugi
and
P. scintilla
( Figs. 107–108a ; 114a), and it can be distinguished from them by the paraproct distinctly shorter than cercus ( Fig. 108a ), whereas in the other two species it is about as long as or slightly longer than cercus ( Figs. 107a ; 114a), and by its mostly pale tibiae (dark in
P. klugi
and
P. scintilla
) and posterior lobe of pronotum with medial 0.5 or less black (entirely black in
P. klugi
and
P. scintilla
). It further differs from them by genital ligula morphology, with distal end straight and laterodistal corners projected into ventral processes with slightly reflected tips ( Fig. 82 ); in
P. klugi
tips of laterodistal processes are bifid ( Fig. 81 ) and in
P. scintilla
the distal end is triangularly convex and laterodistal corners are not projected into ventral processes ( Fig. 88 ). Female of
P. macintyrei
shares an approximately triangular and flat mesostigmal plate with
P. klugi
,
P. sulfurata
,
P. tenuis
, and
P. woytkowskii
(Figs. 57; 58; 66; 68–70). It can be distinguished from them by the presence of a transverse tear-shaped depression with narrowly carinate posterior margin behind mesostigmal plate (Fig. 58), absent in all other species, in which mesepisternum is either smooth (Figs. 66; 68–70) or presents a transverse carina adjacent to mesostigmal plate posterior margin (Fig. 57).
Habitat and biology. Adults found at streams and pools and seeps associated with streams.
